Rule Title: Article element contains heading level that is improperly nested
Description: One or more headings (created using h1 - h6 elements (without an ARIA-assigned role); or elements with a role attribute set to a value that starts with 'heading' and an aria-level attribute set to an appropriate value) inside an article element (excluding the contents of any further enclosed article elements) are not set to a heading level that can be considered as properly nested within the document heading hierarchy.
What is the problem: Article element contains heading level that is improperly nested
Why it matters: When heading levels are skipped in an article, users of screen readers who are blind or low vision may not understand the relationship of sections of content.
What to do: Use heading elements in the proper order within an article element and the surrounding page. For example, a heading level 1 (h1h2). A heading level 2 should not be followed by a heading level 4 (h4). Headings are not required to have sub-heading; for example, a heading level 2 (h2) section need not have any heading below it. A rule of thumb is that in general, the heading level should match the visual representation of the heading level. It is possible to have a h2 followed by an h4 if the h4 represents content that is perhaps lower in structure or importance than a h3 where an h3 might be used elsewhere in the same article. However, if the h4 is really the next logical level after h2 and doesn't match an h4 visually from another part of the same article, or is not of lesser importance such as used in an error message or aside, then it should be an h3 to communicate the structure. Due to lack of support for the HTML5 sectional structure, headings need to align with the order of headings in the containing page and their corresponding HTML numbered heading levels (h1,h2, h3, etc.). or ARIA role="heading" and aria-level.

Description: One or more footer elements, excluding children of article elements (without an ARIA-assigned role) or section elements (without an ARIA-assigned role), not intentionally hidden in the DOM and available to assistive technologies, has a role attribute set to the value: 'contentinfo'.
What to do: Developers must use valid markup and follow the rules of the ARIA specification.

Rule Title: Span element has aria-label that will not be used
Description: One or more span elements, without an ARIA-assigned role, not intentionally hidden in the DOM and available to assistive technologies, has an aria-label attribute.
What is the problem: Span element has aria-label that will not be used
Why it matters: When an authored supplied accessible name is applied to the span element this name will not be seen by screen readers used by people who are blind or visually impaired.
What to do: Remove the accessible name provided by the aria-label. If the information from the aria-label is needed, implement another method to expose that information to the user of assistive technology. For example, add that text on-screen, use a different element with a role that can have an author supplied accessible name or use off-screen CSS text to provide the information to users of screen readers.

Description: One or more elements, excluding elements with a size of 1px by 1px, not intentionally hidden in the DOM, contains text less than 18 point in size; or bold text less than 14 point in size has a luminosity contrast ratio below 4.5:1.
Why it matters: Sufficient contrast helps people with low vision, contrast limitations, or color vision deficiencies to fluently read text.  When text does not have sufficient contrast some users may not be able to read the text or may miss the presence of the text altogether.
What to do: Use sufficient contrast for all text and images of text.  Text is that is not large text (not greater than or equal to 18pt or 14pt bolded), incidental, or a logo needs to have at least a minimum contrast ratio of 4.5:1 to adjacent pixels.  This ratio is a minimum and many users with low vision need and benefit from more contrast to read text.  The color of the text,  background, or both can be adjusted to increase contrast.  Halos, opaque boxes, and other techniques may be useful to increase contrast in situations where text appears over non-solid backgrounds.  Authors need to ensure that contrast is maintained across responsive variations.  Use a Contrast Checker Tool to check the contrast ratio.

Rule Title: Aria-expanded used where it is not allowed
Description: One or more elements, excluding button elements (without an ARIA-assigned role), input type='button | image | reset | submit' elements (without an ARIA-assigned role), summary elements (without an ARIA-assigned role), A elements with an href attribute (without an ARIA-assigned role), area elements with an href attribute (without an ARIA-assigned role), hr elements (without an ARIA-assigned role) and elements with a role='application | button | checkbox | columnheader | combobox | gridcell | link | listbox | menuitem | menuitemcheckbox | menuitemradio | row | rowheader | switch | tab | treeitem' attribute, not intentionally hidden in the DOM and available to assistive technologies, has an aria-expanded attribute.
Code Snippet: <input id="searchInput" type="search" placeholder="Search..." aria-autocomplete="list" aria-expanded="false" aria-controls="searchResults">
What is the problem: Aria-expanded used where it is not allowed
Why it matters: When aria-expanded is incorrectly applied state information needed to understand the content of the page will not be correctly communicated to screen readers.
What to do: Avoid use of the aria-expanded attribute on elements where it is not allowed. To address this issue, an appropriate role may need to be applied such as the role button for a button that expands/collapses additional content, etc. When an aria-expanded attribute is not allowed and no appropriate element or ARIA role is available the ARIA attribute needs to be removed. If the element with the aria-expanded attribute controls the expansion of another grouping container that is not 'owned by' the element, the author needs to reference the container by using the aria-controls attribute.
